questions.question: A 3-year-old girl presents with esotropia, which increases on focusing near objects. This issue has progressively worsened over the past few months, and she has difficulty with close visual tasks. A refractive error of +6.50 D has been identified. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Accommodative refractive esotropia Explanation: The above scenario is a case of accommodative reflex esotropia, which has a convergent squint with high hypermetropia. Esotropia It is an inward deviation of one eye and is the most common type of squint in children. It is of the following types: Infantile esotropia (Option D) - onset is before 6 months and mostly bilateral in presentation Accommodative esotropia Accommodative refractive esotropia Accommodative non-refractive esotropia Accommodative mixed esotropia Acquired Nonaccommodative esotropia Sensory esotropia Consecutive esotropia Accommodative esotropia Accommodative Refractive Esotropia (Option A) Accommodative Non-refractive Esotropia (Option B) Accommodative Mixed Esotropia (Option C) Cause High hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D) Abnormal large AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio Combination of hypermetropia and high AC/ A ratio Treatment Correction of hypermetropia (spectacles) Corrected by bifocal glasses with +3 DS added for near vision Miotics (Echothiophate) Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Page 979, 980, 982. Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Page 1212, 1213. Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 7th edition, Page 363.

questions.question: A 7-year old child is brought to the clinic by her parents due to concerns about her right eyes appearing misaligned. On examination, her squint remains constant in all directions of gaze. She does not report any diplopia, and there are no limitations in eye movement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Concomitant squint Explanation: The squint remains constant in all directions of gaze with no associated diplopia, suggesting that it is a case of concomitant squint. Squint/Strabismus: Misalignment of the visual axis. This condition is also called Heterotropia. Classification: It is divided into latent squint (phorias) and manifest (tropia). Latent squint - classification Hyperphoria Exophoria Esophoria Manifest squint - classification Esotropia/Exotropia/Hypertropia Concomitant/Incomitant squint Concomitant: Esotropia/Exotropia Incomitant: Paralytic (paralysis of the muscles) Restrictive squint (fibrosis of the muscles) A-V pattern or pattern squint Ocular motility defects Concomitant squint: It's a type of manifest squint in which the angle of deviation remains equal in all the 9 gazes ; there is no associated limitation of ocular movements (Option A) . Primary deviation is equal to secondary deviation . Primary deviation is the amount of deviation in a squinted eye. Secondary deviation: It is the amount of deviation in the normal eye (behind the cover). Concomitant squint commonly occurs during early childhood or can be congenital (congenital squint). Eye movements are normal and no double vision (diplopia). Amblyopia develops later (negative adaptation). Abnormal retinal correspondence also plays a role. It is a positive adaptation. Incomitant squint (Option B): This condition is just the opposite of concomitant squints, where the degree of squint varies in different aspects. Secondary deviation is higher than primary deviation in paralytic squint. In contrast to concomitant squints, there is a late presentation. There is palsy of other muscles, which causes limited ocular movements (ocular movements are restricted). Diplopia is also a very important feature of inconcomitant squints. Paralytic squint (Option C): Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint in which ocular deviation results from complete or incomplete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles. History of diplopia and confusion Secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation. Ocular movements are restricted towards the action of paralyzed muscle. Head is turned towards the action of paralyzed muscle. Pseudo-strabismus (Option D): Pseudostrabismus is a condition when the eyes are well aligned but appear to be misaligned. Causes of Pseudo-esotropia: Epicanthal folds High myopia (high negative angle kappa) Causes of Pseudo-Exotropia: Telecanthus or hypertelorism High hypermetropia (high positive angle kappa) Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pages 1211, 1217

questions.question: A 65 year old woman presented to the OPD with her head tilted towards the right side. On examination, she was having left hypertropia which increases on looking right or medially. The muscle which is most likely paralyzed is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Left superior oblique Explanation: The Park 3-step test is a diagnostic test used to identify which muscle is paretic in the case of an acquired hypertropia. It is designed for the diagnosis of a single paretic vertical muscle and is unreliable when there are multiple paretic muscles or in restrictive strabismus. Applying the Park 3-step test : Which eye is hypertropic? The left eye is hypertropic, meaning the affected muscle must be either: A depressor of the left eye ( superior oblique or inferior rectus ) An elevator of the right eye ( superior rectus or inferior oblique ) Does hypertropia increase in the right gaze? Yes, → This suggests a problem with the left superior oblique or the right superior rectus . Does hypertropia increase on the left or right head tilt? The question doesn't explicitly state this, but given the patient's right head tilt , it suggests a compensatory posture. In superior oblique palsy , the head tilts opposite the affected muscle to minimize diplopia. This means the actual hypertropia worsens with a left tilt , confirming left superior oblique palsy . Final Diagnosis: Left superior oblique palsy → Compensatory right head tilt . Reference: (PDF) Keys to Solve Park-3 Step Test (researchgate.net) Three Step Test for Cyclovertical Muscle Palsy - EyeWiki

questions.question: A 40-year-old patient presents for binocular vision assessment. The ophthalmologist performs the Worth’s Four Dot Test. The patient wears red-green glasses and reports seeing three green dots. What does this finding most likely indicate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Suppression of right eye Explanation: If the patient only sees three green dots, it suggests suppression of the right eye, as the red lens over the right eye would normally allow them to see the red dot. The fact that only green dots are seen indicates that the right eye is not contributing to vision. WORTH’S FOUR DOT TEST Patient wears goggles with red lens in front of the right eye and green lens in front of the left eye, and views a box with 4 lights - one red, two green and one white. Results are interpreted as below: Normal binocular single vision (Option D) : Patient sees all the four lights in the absence of manifest squint (image A) . Abnormal retinal correspondence: Patient sees all four lights even in the presence of a manifest squint. Left eye suppression (Option C) : Patient sees only two red lights (Image B) . Right eye suppression (Option B) : Patient sees only three green lights (Image C) . Alternating suppression: Patient sees three green lights and two red lights, alternately. Diplopia (Option A) : Patient sees 5 lights (2 red and 3 green) (Image D & E) .

questions.question: During a Maddox rod test, the patient is asked to view a distant light source. With the Maddox rod placed in front of the right eye, the patient reports seeing a vertical red line to the right of the white light. What type of ocular misalignment does this result suggest?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Esophoria Explanation: In the Maddox rod test, if the vertical red line (seen by the right eye) appears to the right of the white light, it suggests that the eyes are converging, which is indicative of esophoria . MADDOX ROD TEST Patient is asked to fixate on a point light in the centre of a Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye with the axis of rod parallel to the axis of deviation. The Maddox rod converts the point source into a line. Thus, the patient will see a point light with one eye and a red line with the other. Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest . Measure the Horizontal Deviation with Maddox rod test The red lines of the Maddox rod are placed horizontally in front of the right eye so that a vertical line is formed. The patient is then asked whether the white light is superimposed on the horizontal red line or not. Patient might see the light source right or left to the red line. If superimposed - normal . If the patient is seeing the red line to the left of point light: Exotropia or crossed diplopia (as image moves inwards, eye moves outwards). (Option B) If the patient is seeing the red line to the right of point light: Esotropia or uncrossed diplopia . (Option A) Measure the Vertical Deviation with Maddox rod test The red lines of the Maddox rod are placed vertically in front of the right eye so that a horizontal line is formed. The patient is then asked whether the white light is superimposed on the horizontal red line or not. Patient might see the point light source up or down to the horizontal line. If superimposed - normal/orthophoria . If the point light source is above the red line: right hyperphoria or left hypophoria . (Option C) If the point light source is below the red line: right hypophoria or left hyperphoria . (Option D)

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with eyelid retraction on downgaze. He has a history of ocular nerve injury. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pseudo-Von Graefe Sign Explanation: Pseudo-Von Graefe Sign is due to aberrant regeneration of the third cranial nerve following a palsy. The co-contraction of the levator palpebrae superioris and inferior rectus muscles leads to eyelid retraction on downgaze , distinguishing it from other conditions. This Pseudo-Von Graefe Sign is not associated with pupil abnormalities, and the pupil typically remains unaffected. Von Graefe’s Sign (Option A) is seen in Graves’ disease , characterised by delayed descent of the upper eyelid during downgaze caused by restrictive orbitopathy affecting the eyelid. Hutchinson’s Pupil (Option B): Typically seen in uncal herniation , characterised by a unilateral dilated pupil that is unresponsive to light due to compression of the third cranial nerve, often associated with raised intracranial pressure. Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Phenomenon (Option D) involves ptosis that improves with jaw movement due to aberrant innervation between the trigeminal nerve (motor division for the jaw) and the levator palpebrae superioris. questions.question: A 7-year-old girl has limited abduction of the left eye, with globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction and widening of the fissure on attempted abduction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Duane Retraction Syndrome Type I Explanation: The child presents with: Limited abduction of the left eye Globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction Widening of the palpebral fissure on attempted abduction This clinical picture is characteristic of Duane Retraction Syndrome (DRS) Type I , the most common subtype. Duane Retraction Syndrome (DRS) Feature Type I Type II Type III Abduction Limited Normal Limited Adduction Normal or mildly limited Limited Limited Globe Retraction Present on adduction Variable Present on adduction Palpebral Fissure on Adduction Narrows Slight change Narrows Palpebral Fissure on Abduction Widens No significant change Slight change Pathophysiology Absent CN VI; CN III innervates LR CN III innervates LR Co-contraction of LR and MR Type I is due to congenital absence or hypoplasia of the abducens nerve (CN VI) . The lateral rectus is instead innervated by branches of the oculomotor nerve (CN III) , causing co-contraction of the lateral and medial recti during adduction. Key Clinical Findings in DRS Type I: Eye fails to abduct normally On adduction, the eye retracts into the orbit Narrowing of the palpebral fissure due to globe retraction Widening of the palpebral fissure during attempted abduction Duane Retraction Syndrome Type II (Option B): Incorrect because it shows limited adduction with normal abduction, which is the reverse of this case. Duane Retraction Syndrome Type III (Option C): Incorrect as both abduction and adduction are limited , not just abduction. Sixth Cranial Nerve Palsy (Option D): Incorrect because, although there is limited abduction , there is no globe retraction or palpebral fissure change on adduction. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Page 1215

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with the following symptoms: right-sided facial weakness, right-sided lateral gaze impairment, and weakness on the left side of the body. Imaging reveals a ventral pontine lesion. Which of the following syndromes best describes this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Millard-Gubler Syndrome Explanation: The Given Clinical scenario with facial weakness, lateral gaze impairment & weakness on the left side of the body along with ventral pontine lesion points toward Millard-Gubler Syndrome Syndromes Associated with Abducens Nerve: Syndromes Cause Features Foville Syndrome (Option D) Damage to the dorsal pontine area affects the abducens nucleus, facial nucleus, and descending corticospinal fibres. Sixth Nerve Palsy Seventh Nerve Palsy Contralateral Hemiparesis Central Horner Syndrome Millard-Gubler Syndrome (Option B) Ventral pontine injury affects the abducens nerve fascicle and facial nerve fibres. Lateral Rectus Weakness Ipsilateral facial paralysis Contralateral Hemiparesis Moebius Syndrome (Option C) Congenital condition affecting cranial nerve development. Facial Nerve Palsy Eye Movement Abnormalities : The eyes may exhibit esotropia (inward turning) or exotropia (outward turning). Orofacial Dysmorphism : Abnormalities in facial structure, which may include difficulty with suckling and phonation in infants. Gradenigo Syndrome (Option A) Mastoiditis leads to infection and inflammation near the petrous apex of the temporal bone. Abducens Nerve Palsy : Difficulty moving the eye laterally, often associated with pain. Facial Pain : Pain may be present due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve. Deafness : Associated with mastoiditis, which results in pain and deafness. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Page 1215 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 230

questions.question: A 45-year-old man has double vision and an inward deviation of his left eye. On examination it is found to be associated with 6th Cranial Nerve Palsy. What finding is typical for sixth cranial nerve palsy?

options.C: Head turn towards the same side, avoiding diplopia

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Head turn towards the same side, avoiding diplopia Explanation: In sixth cranial nerve palsy, the affected eye cannot abduct properly, leading to diplopia that often improves with a head turn towards the affected side. This compensatory mechanism helps align the eyes to avoid double vision. Sixth Cranial Nerve Palsy: Causes : Typically caused by infarction, demyelination, or compression from intrinsic pontine tumors. Features: Esotropia (inward eye deviation) due to Lateral rectus palsy - Restricted Abduction of the affected eye Ipsilateral Horizontal Gaze Palsy (Option A) Often compensated by turning their head toward the affected side. (Option C) Pupil function remains unaffected (Option B) Long-Term Effects: Muscle Changes : Prolonged palsy may cause tightening and contracture of the medial rectus muscle, leading to restrictive strabismus. Associated Syndromes: One-and-a-Half Syndrome: I/L gaze palsy and internuclear ophthalmoplegia Foville Syndrome: Lateral Gaze Palsy, Ipsilateral Facial Palsy, Contralateral Hemiparesis Millard Gubler Syndrome: I/L 6,7 Cranial nerve palsy with C/L Hemiplegia Management: Acute Phase : Manage diplopia with eye patching or frosting a spectacle lens; prisms are often not well tolerated. Surgical Intervention : Indicated if the deviation stabilises for at least 6 months. Choices depend on lateral rectus muscle function: Good Function : Ipsilateral recess-resect procedure. Poor Function : Muscle transposition surgery may be needed. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pages 933, 934

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient reports diplopia and is found to have left trochlear nerve palsy. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with it?

options.B: No diplopia with head tilt away from the left side
options.D: Increase in hypertropia on opposite gaze

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Diplopia relieves while going downstairs Explanation: In trochlear nerve palsy, there is vertical diplopia which worsens while going downstairs Trochlear Nerve (CN IV): Nucleus is located in the midbrain, near the inferior colliculus & the only cranial nerve that exits from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem . It is the smallest of the cranial nerves, while having the longest intracranial course . Innervates the contralateral superior oblique muscle Nuclear Lesion : Causes contralateral superior oblique muscle palsy. Cavernous / Orbital Lesion : Results in ipsilateral superior oblique muscle palsy. Trochlear Nerve (CN IV) Palsy: Congenital : May become apparent at any age. Children often have abnormal head postures; adults may experience intermittent diplopia. Acquired : Most commonly due to trauma & presents with more noticeable symptoms. Clinical Features: Hypertropia (Option C) Increase in hypertropia on opposite gaze (Option D) Excyclotorsion (outward rotational movement of the eye) Vertical Diplopia - Increases on Downgaze (Option A) Depressed Chin with face towards the opposite side Head tilt towards the opposite side (Option B) Poor depression in adduction is typical. Crossed Diplopia Management: Resolution: Vascular issues/trauma often resolve spontaneously within 3–6 months. Compressive Lesions: Require surgical intervention. Surgical Treatment: (Knapp Management) Inferior Oblique Weakening Enhancing Superior Oblique Action Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pages 932, 934 Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Page 992

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with the following findings. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: disorder caused by the fibrous tightening of the superior oblique tendon, causing a restriction in eye movement due to issues, and is not associated with third cranial nerve (CN III) palsy. Syndromes associated with Third Cranial Nerve Palsy (Oculomotor Nerve): Syndrome Cause Features Weber's Syndrome Injury to cerebral peduncle. Third nerve palsy on the same side (ipsilateral) as the affected eye, combined with contralateral hemiplegia (paralysis on the opposite side of the body). Benedict's Syndrome Injury to the Red nucleus Third nerve palsy with contralateral hemi-tremors, chorea & athetosis. Nothnagel's Syndrome Injury to the Superior Cerebellar Peduncle Third nerve palsy with ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia (balance and coordination problems on the same side as the affected eye). Claude's Syndrome Lesion in the midbrain affects both the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the red nucleus. Third nerve palsy, ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, and contralateral hemi-tremors. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Page 931, 932 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 231 AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology, 7th Edition, Page 372

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset double vision and difficulty aligning his eyes, which began three weeks ago. He has a history of hypertension and recently experienced a mild stroke. Examination reveals that his eye is positioned downward and outward. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Accommodation increases Explanation: The given scenario is diagnosed as paralytic strabismus, caused by 3rd nerve (oculomotor) palsy in which accommodation is completely lost due to paralysis of the ciliary muscles. Features of third nerve palsy Ptosis: Due to paralysis of the LPS (levator palpebrae superioris) muscle The eyeball is deviated down and outwards (due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles). The pupil is fixed and dilated (due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle) Ocular movements are restricted Accommodation is completely lost (due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle) Crossed diplopia is elicited by raising the eyelid. Absence of Both direct and consensual reflexes in the affected eye These compensatory head postures are motor adaptations used to minimise the effects of double vision Horizontal Diplopia: The patient often tilts the head downward Vertical Diplopia: The head is positioned with the chin either raised or lowered Torsional Diplopia: The head is tilted sideways

questions.question: How much is the difference in deviation between upward gaze and downward gaze in A-V pattern strabismus? ≥ 10 PD, V-pattern ≥ 15 PD ≥ 15 PD, V-pattern ≥ 10 PD ≤ 10 PD, V-pattern ≤ 15 PD ≤ 15 PD, V-pattern ≤ 10 PD
questions.explanation: ≥ 10 PD, V-pattern ≥ 15 PD Correct Answer: A) A pattern ≥ 10 PD, V pattern ≥ 15 PD Explanation: The difference between upgaze and downgaze in A-V pattern strabismus is A-pattern ≥ 10 PD, V-pattern ≥ 15 PD. A-V Pattern Squint It consists of an A-pattern and a V-pattern. Causes: Oblique muscle dysfunction (most common) Rectus muscle dysfunction Amount of deviation ‘A’ pattern ‘V’ pattern Between upward and downward gaze ≥ 10 PD or prism dioptre ≥ 15 PD or prism dioptre Esotropia (in upward gaze) Increases Decreases Esotropia (in downward gaze) Decreases Increases Exotropia (in upward gaze) Decreases Increases Exotropia (in downward gaze) Increases Decreases

questions.question: A 45-year-old male complains of double vision, describing seeing two overlapping images when looking in a specific direction. He reports that this problem started suddenly about two weeks ago and is most noticeable when looking towards the right side. There is no history of trauma. On examination, he has limited movement of the right eye towards the right. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Paralytic strabismus Explanation: The given scenario is diagnosed as binocular diplopia most commonly caused by paralysis of extra ocular muscles (paralytic strabismus). Diplopia refers to the simultaneous perception of two images of a single object. It can be classified in the following ways, 1. It is classified as: 2. It can also be classified as, Horizontal diplopia Vertical diplopia Torsional diplopia Causes of diplopia: Uniocular diplopia Binocular diplopia Subluxation of lens (Option C) Polycoria (multiple pupils) Incipient cataract Keratoconus Paralysis of extraocular muscles (e.g. paralytic strabismus) (Option D) Orbital lesions Orbital fractures (e.g. blowout fracture) (Option A) Thick pterygium (Option B) Symblepharon Thyroid ophthalmopathy Decentred spectacles Anisometropia Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Page 211. Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Page 935. Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 7th edition, Page 357.

questions.question: Which of the following is known for its specific pattern of muscle insertions around the sclera, essential for the alignment and movement of the extraocular muscles?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Spiral of Tillaux Explanation: The Spiral of Tillaux refers to the spiral arrangement of the insertion points of the extraocular muscles on the sclera, which is essential for coordinating eye movements and maintaining proper ocular alignment. Order of Insertion (Spiral of Tillaux): Medial Rectus Inserts closest to the limbus, about 5.5 mm from the limbus. Inferior Rectus Inserts 6.5 mm from the limbus. Lateral Rectus Inserts 6.9 mm from the limbus Superior Rectus Inserts the farthest, about 7.7 mm from the limbus. Annulus of Zinn (Option A) is a fibrous ring at the back of the orbit around the optic nerve. It serves as the origin for the four rectus muscles (lateral, medial, superior, and inferior), providing a stable attachment point that allows these muscles to control eye movement.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child is having trouble catching a ball, climbing stairs, and performing fine motor tasks. She has a tendency to avoid activities requiring precise hand skills. No developmental delay was detected. Which of the following tests would be appropriate for diagnosing her condition?
questions.explanation: appropriate test is the Titmus fly test. Stereopsis is the ability to perceive the 3rd dimension (depth perception). Titmus fly test: The patient has to wear polarized glass, and the fly will be seen from different angles. Evaluate how well the child can perceive the relative depth of the images. HESS chart (Option A) is used to measure the degree of deviation, especially if torsional, and particularly to measure any progressive increase or decrease by Hess screen test . The patient wears red goggles over the right eye and green goggles over the left eye. To test a specific eye, the green goggles are placed in front of it while the red goggles serve as a fixator. The patient aligns a green light with a red light projected on an electronic board. After the test, the goggles are switched so the green goggles are no longer in front of the right eye. Cover-uncover test (Option B) This test is used to detect manifest (tropia) and latent (phoria) strabismus by covering one eye and then uncovering it to observe any corrective movement. It evaluates ocular misalignment, not depth perception. Maddox rod test (Option D) is used for detection of latent squint. By convention, the Maddox rod is always placed over the right eye and the patient is asked to fixate on a bright white light either at distance or near. A binocular patient’s right eye sees a red line, while the uncovered left eye sees the white light.

questions.question: The parents of an 8-month-old girl have observed her eyes misaligning, especially when she focuses on objects up close, with one eye occasionally turning inward. They consulted an ophthalmologist, who conducted the test shown below. What is the name of this test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bruckner test Explanation: The above image depicts the Bruckner test , showing a brighter reflex in a squinted eye . Bruckner Test: The infant is seated on the mother’s lap while the lights are dimmed. The examiner sits at arm’s length in front of the patient and shines the beam of a direct ophthalmoscope onto the patient’s eyes, wide enough to illuminate both eyes simultaneously. Fundus reflex is depicted as, Squinted eye: Brighter reflex Fixing eye (normal eye) : Dark or dull reflex Hirschberg test (Option A) involves throwing light into the eye from a distance and the patient is asked to look at the light (an infant does this reflexively). A rough indication of the angle of the squint can be obtained from the position of the corneal reflex. Prism cover test (Option C): Prisms of increasing strength with an apex towards the deviation are placed in front of one eye, and the

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy's parents noticed his left eye turning inward, especially when tired or focusing on near objects. An ophthalmologist diagnosed strabismus and performed the test shown below. Which statements about this test are correct?

options.A: It indicates the angle of squint
options.B: In an aligned eye, the reflex is centred

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The above image depicts Hirschberg’s test, which is used to indicate the angle of squint by measuring the light reflex on the cornea. Hirschberg’s Test The angle of the squint can be roughly estimated by observing the position of the corneal reflex when light is directed into the eye. (Option A) Procedure : Light is thrown into the eye with the ophthalmoscope or a focused light beam from a torch. The patient is asked to fixate at a point light held at a distance. In the fixing eye, the corneal reflex will be in the centre of the pupil. (Option B) The light is observed to be decentred in the squinting eye as, Pupillary border: 18-20° (outer: 20°, inner: 18°). Between the limbus and the papillary border: 35°. At the limbus: 45°. (Option C)

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with eye strain and headaches. The ophthalmologist plans to perform a series of tests to evaluate the patient’s strabismus. All of the following are objective tests used to assess strabismus except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Maddox Rod test Explanation: The Maddox Rod Test is primarily subjective . It requires the patient to interpret the position of lines projected onto their retina, and their perception is used to measure the angle of deviation. This contrasts with purely objective tests, which rely on direct measurements or observations without relying on the patient's subjective interpretation of visual stimuli. Maddox Rod Test: Procedure: The patient is positioned in front of a bright spot of light in a dark room. A Maddox rod, consisting of multiple red glass cylinders or a Maddox groove disc, is placed in a trial frame before one eye. Testing Horizontal Deviation: Cylinders Horizontal: The red line seen through the Maddox rod will be vertical. Observation: If there is no horizontal deviation ( orthophoria ), the bright spot of light will align with the vertical red line. Esophoria: The red line will appear to the right of the light (uncrossed diplopia). Exophoria: The red line will appear to the left of the light (crossed diplopia). Testing Vertical Deviation: Cylinders Vertical: The red line will be horizontal. Observation: If there is no vertical deviation, the red line will pass through the light. Hyperphoria: If the red line appears above or below the light, it indicates hyperphoria. The direction of the deviation helps identify whether the right or left eye is affected. List of Objective and Subjective Tests for Ocular Alignment and Function: Objective Tests Subjective Tests Corneal Light Reflex Test (Hirschberg Test, Krimsky Test) Bruckner Test Cover-Uncover Test Prism Bar Test Synoptophore Maddox Rod Test Maddox Wing Test Lancaster Red-Green Test Hess Screen Haploscopic Devices (Major Amblyoscope)

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with increased diplopia on upward gaze and restricted movement of the left eye. The patient also has a history of recent orbital trauma. To determine whether the limitation is due to a mechanical restriction or a nerve palsy, which of the following tests is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Forced duction test Explanation: The forced duction test is the primary method used to determine whether an eye movement limitation is due to mechanical restriction or a paralytic condition. Mechanical Tests of Eye Movement Limitations: Mechanical tests help differentiate between eye movement limitations due to paralysis, paresis, or mechanical restriction. 1. Forced Duction Test: Purpose: To determine if a limitation in eye movement is due to mechanical restriction or nerve palsy. Procedure: Apply topical anaesthetic to the limbal conjunctiva. The patient is instructed to look in the direction of the movement being tested, and the maximum eye range is observed. Using toothed forceps to grasp the conjunctiva, the examiner holds the eye at the opposite limbus and attempts to rotate it as far as possible in the same direction. Interpretation: Positive Test: Resistance to movement indicates a mechanical restriction (e.g., dysthyroid orbitopathy, muscle entrapment). Negative Test: No resistance suggests a nerve palsy, as the eye can be moved freely. 2. Testing Oblique Muscles: To test the superior and inferior obliques. 3. Active Force Generation Test: To assess the strength of muscle contraction against resistance. Hess Screen Test (Option A) measures the degree of misalignment but does not differentiate between mechanical restriction and nerve palsy directly. Cover Test (Option C) is useful for detecting and measuring deviations but not for determining the cause of limited movement. Worth’s 4-Dot Test (Option D) assesses binocular vision and suppression but does not provide specific information about mechanical restrictions or nerve palsy.

questions.question: A 10-year-old patient presents to the clinic with complaints of occasional double vision and eye strain during schoolwork. On examination, you suspect she may have a squint and perform the following test. What is this test known as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cover-Uncover Test Explanation : The given image is of Cover-Uncover Test which is used to differentiate between latent squint (heterophoria) and manifest squint (heterotopia). Cover test: Detects Heterotropia (Manifest Squint) Uncover test: Detects Heterophoria (Latent Squint) Cover-Uncover Test: The cover and uncover tests assess horizontal and vertical strabismus, but not torsional deviations. They also evaluate the ability of each eye to fixate on a target. Cover Test: Detects Tropias: Measures constant deviations of the visual axis. Procedure: Cover one eye with a paddle, thumb, or occluder. Observe the uncovered eye for movement: Nasal movement: Exotropia Temporal movement: Esotropia Upward movement: Hypotropia Downward movement: Hypertropia For young children, use small toys instead of bright lights. Quantify the deviation with the simultaneous prism and cover test by introducing a prism before one eye until movement stops. Repeat with the prism before the other eye. Uncover Test: Identifies latent deviations or tropias. Procedure: Cover one eye and then observe the covered eye when the cover is removed. If the eye reverts to fixation, it indicates a phoria or intermittent tropia . Alternate Cover Test: Detects phorias by dissociating the visual axes. Alternate covering each eye to maximize visual axis dissociation. Care must be taken to permit time for each eye to reside behind the cover (the cover must not be “fanned” before the eyes). questions.question: Which of the following options correctly identifies the type of strabismus depicted in each image? 1. 2. 3.
Which mechanism is responsible for maintaining coordinated movement of both eyes and achieving binocular vision?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: All of the above mechanisms are responsible for maintaining coordinated movement of both eyes and achieving binocular vision Mechanism of Binocular Vision Formation: Binocular vision relies on the precise coordination of extraocular muscles in both eyes, ensuring single, clear vision through complex neural mechanisms. Key components of this system include: Conjugate & Dysconjugate Movements (Option A) Synkinesis refers to the simultaneous movement of both eyes in the same direction, essential for maintaining binocular alignment. This is known as conjugate movement . Dysconjugate movements occur when the eyes move in opposite directions, such as during convergence (both eyes move inward) or divergence (both eyes move outward). Synergistic & Antagonistic Muscles (Option B) Synergistic muscles contract together to move both eyes in a specific direction. Eg: In Dextroversion (rightward gaze), the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus act as synergists. Antagonistic muscles are those that relax or are inhibited during these movements. Eg: In Dextroversion, the right medial rectus and left lateral rectus are antagonists. Yoke Muscles (Option C) Yoke muscles are pairs of synergistic muscles in each eye that work together to achieve coordinated eye movements. Eg: In the Rightward gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus are yoke muscles that contract together to move the eyes in the same direction. Neurological Control Hering's Law of Equal Innervation ensures that both eyes receive equal and simultaneous neural input to the synergistic (yoke) muscles during conjugate movements. Sherrington's Law of Reciprocal Innervation states that increased activation of a muscle is accompanied by decreased activation of its direct antagonist muscle. Ocular Motor Nuclei and Pathways The control of eye movements involves several brainstem nuclei, including the oculomotor (III) , trochlear (IV) , and abducens (VI) nuclei. These nuclei coordinate eye movements through neural pathways, such as the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) , which connects various eye movement centres. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Pages 931, 933

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with diplopia and difficulty looking upwards and to the right, with limited elevation of the right eye. You suspect a lesion affecting a muscle responsible for vertical movement. Which axis describes the rotational movement, and which muscle is likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Fick's x-axis; Right Superior Rectus Explanation: The vertical movements of the eye occur with the x axis as the centre of rotation in primary position. The right superior rectus elevates the eye, particularly in the direction of upward gaze. A lesion in the right superior rectus explains the patient's difficulty with upward movement. Axis Direction Movements Muscles Involved X-Axis (Horizontal) Runs horizontally from the outer corner to the inner corner. Elevation (upward) and Depression (downward) Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus Y-Axis (Anteroposterior) Runs anteroposteriorly from the front (cornea) to the back. Intorsion (inward rotation) and Extorsion (outward rotation) Superior Oblique, Inferior Oblique Z-Axis (Vertical) Runs vertically from the top of the head to the chin. Adduction (inward) and Abduction (outward) Medial Rectus, Lateral Rectus Listing’s Plane is a conceptual plane that passes through the eye’s centre of rotation and is perpendicular to the visual axis when the eye is in a straight-ahead gaze. It describes how the eye rotates when moving from the primary position to any other direction and helps explain the torsional movements the eye makes to maintain visual stability.

questions.question: Which physiological principle explains that during eye movement, an increase in neural stimulation to a contracting muscle is accompanied by a proportional decrease in stimulation to its opposing muscle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sherrington’s Law Explanation: Sherrington’s Law of Reciprocal Innervation of the same eye, states that when one muscle contracts (agonist), its opposing muscle (antagonist) in the same eye must relax to allow coordinated movement. Hering’s Law (Option A) refers to the equal innervation of corresponding eye muscles to ensure simultaneous and symmetrical movements. Henle’s law of accommodation (Option C) refers to anatomical observations related to the length-tension relationship in muscles, particularly in the context of accommodation in the eye. Donder’s Law (Option D) pertains to the torsional movements of the eye. Reference: Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Page 1194

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents with a condition in which, upon examination, the left eye fails to adduct during right gaze. The patient reports diplopia, which is more noticeable when looking to the right. Which extraocular muscle is most likely overacting in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Right Lateral Rectus Explanation: Given that the left eye fails to adduct and diplopia is more noticeable during right gaze, it suggests that the left medial rectus is not functioning properly. Hering’s Law of Equal Innervation would mean that the right lateral rectus (yoke muscle) should be balanced with the left medial rectus ( vs Sherrington’s law: This law about reciprocal innervation states that increased innervation and contraction of a muscle is automatically associated with reciprocal decrease in innervation and contraction of its antagonist). If the left medial rectus is weak or underacting, the corresponding yoke muscle, the right lateral rectus, might be compensating and thus appearing to overact. Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles, one in each eye, that work together to ensure coordinated eye movements in the same direction. These muscles function according to Hering's Law of Equal Innervation , which ensures that corresponding muscles in both eyes receive equal neural impulses for synchronised movement. The yoke muscle pairs facilitate various eye movements: Horizontal Gaze (Left or Right) : Leftward Gaze (Levoversion) : Left Lateral Rectus (abducts the left eye) Right Medial Rectus (adducts the right eye) Rightward Gaze (Dextroversion) : Right Lateral Rectus (abducts the right eye) Left Medial Rectus (adducts the left eye) Vertical Gaze (Up or Down) : Upward Gaze (Elevation) : Right and Left Superior Rectus (elevate the eyes) Right and Left Inferior Oblique (assist in elevation) Downward Gaze (Depression) : Right and Left Inferior Rectus (depress the eyes) Right and Left Superior Oblique (assist in depression) Inward Gaze (Convergence) : Both Medial Rectus muscles contract to bring the eyes inward (toward the nose) during near-vision tasks, such as reading.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with vertical diplopia that worsens when looking down, especially while walking downstairs. Examination reveals weakness in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the affected eye. Which muscle and cranial nerve are most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Superior Oblique; Trochlear nerve (CN IV) Explanation: The superior oblique muscle , innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) , is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye. Dysfunction of this muscle causes vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when looking down, such as when walking downstairs.
